title: HIV: Viral Load and Stigma

content: There are numbers we keep up with – like how much our utility bill goes up or down each month, our pay rate at work, and the price of groceries. Some medical conditions have numbers too – conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure, and HIV.

HIV has a number it’s important to know. That’s your viral load, an indication of how much of the virus is found in your blood. The lower the number, the better. That’s because HIV breaks down your immune system. You can get your viral load so low, it’s below detectable levels. (This is called undetectable.) When you’re undetectable, you can’t transmit the virus sexually. But the higher your viral load number is, the more you may be contagious or sick.
HIV viral load is easily controlled these days, with modern medicine. Since 1996, antiretroviral meds have changed the face of HIV, converting it into a chronic condition. And the progress continues.

Today, there are one-pill-a-day regimens, injections that last for months, and the future hope of an implant option. There’s also a medication that can prevent someone who doesn’t have HIV from getting it, and a medication to protect you after exposure to HIV.

content: Modern medicine has changed everything about HIV. Except stigma.

So, it’s important to know what an undetectable viral load means. It's practically a cure. I call it a “functional cure,” because the virus is unable to reproduce itself. it’s like it’s not even there. You can’t transmit it, you’re not susceptible to opportunistic diseases or illnesses, and you can live a long, healthy, dignified, and productive life. Isn’t that a “functional cure”?

But be ready for the denial. Because some people don’t want to believe you when you tell them. They may say they understand, but they won’t have sex with you, and they may break off your relationship.

It’s like the facts don’t matter. They’re still so afraid that they refuse to accept modern facts. They don’t accept that medicines have come a long way and are reliable, they don’t believe you can be untransmittable, and getting them to believe this seems nearly impossible.

content: So, it’s not explaining viral load that’s challenging, and it’s not getting people to understand what it means either. It’s getting others to believe you that’s the problem.

Stigma surrounding HIV is so strong and monumental, it overrides truth. It’s so pervasive, it encompasses pretty much all of society. It’s an epidemic of its own. An epidemic that’s more dangerous and deadly than the virus itself.

Ignorance is the seed of all kinds of false fears, discriminations, and hate. Breaking through walls that some build around their minds is difficult, to say the least. But we must confront the ignorance harming those who live with HIV with facts that can save lives as much as modern medication.
That confrontation with ignorance starts with inward reflection.
Do you believe old facts and misinformation about HIV and AIDS? Can I persuade you to believe modern science that makes HIV harmless and incapable of transmission?

content: This epidemic must be eradicated one mind at a time, starting with ourselves. We must let go of beliefs that are no longer valid and embrace a new reality. It’s the cure still needed for this disease.
